slides.title: Slicing a charge .
slides.originalNotes:
Slicing a charge
The charge invoicing process divides a charge into invoice items and assigns the items to invoices. The appropriate method of dividing a new charge may differ depending on the charge type. BillingCenter determines how to slice charges on a charge- by-charge basis.

The following list summarizes typical charge slicing behaviors in the base configuration:

An issuance charge is sliced into invoice items according to payment plan settings. By default, rewrites, renewals, and cancellations are also sliced according to the payment plan.
A policy change charge is sliced to match the planned installments of an existing charge if the charge can be matched with one or more charges already on the policy.
If special handling is requested on a billing instruction, each charge is sliced into a single invoice item. Special handling instructions are discussed later in this lesson.

For details on how BillingCenter slices charges, refer to the EInvoicing by policy transaction type" chapter in the BillingCenter Application Guide.

slides.title: Policy change overview
slides.originalNotes:
Policy change overview
A policy change usually happens at the request of the policyholder who wants to add or remove coverages or modify the scope of existing coverages.

Charges for a policy change can be negative or positive. A positive charge is typically for adding a coverage to a policy or increasing an existing coverage, whereas a negative charge is typically the result of removing a coverage from a policy or decreasing a coverage. A policy change billing instruction can contain both positive and negative charges.

BillingCenter slices both positive and negative charges into invoice items and then assigns the invoice items to invoices. For negative charges only, BillingCenter uses the negative invoice items to pay for unpaid positive invoice items. This process is called credit allocation and is under the control of the return premium allocation plan, which is discussed later in this lesson.

slides.title: Special handling for policy change
slides.originalNotes:
Special handling for policy change
In some cases, there is a requirement to bill policy changes earlier or later than normal. For example, if the policy change billing request is for a single charge for a small amount of money, the PAS may not want the charge to be broken into installments. Instead, the entire charge can be billed on the next invoice.

A billing instruction can have one (and only one) special handling instruction, which overrides the way in which invoice items for charges are usually scheduled. The default behavior for processing charges on a billing instruction that includes a special handling instruction is to slice each charge into a single invoice item.

The slide lists the three special handling instruction types that are relevant to policy change charges. There is a fourth type, Hold for Final Audit (Billed Items Only), which is applicable to cancellations.

Note: If a billing instruction has a special handling instruction, BillingCenter ignores any payment plan override values.

slides.title: Return premium plan controls allocation of credits [5
slides.originalNotes:
Return premium plan controls allocation of credits
The return premium plan has rules for identifying the invoice items that are eligible to be paid by money released from a credit. It also tells BillingCenter how to prioritize the eligible items if there is not enough money to pay all of them. The Default Return Premium Plan is shipped with BillingCenter.

Whenever a new policy is issued, the active plan is automatically associated with the new policy period and remains associated with the policy period for the period’s entire life. You can modify a plan's settings- However, assigning a different plan to the policy period requires configuration- When a return premium plan's settings are modified, all policy periods associated with the plan use the updated settings for all future credits.

The Eligible Items field specifies which items are eligible for credit. In all cases, the eligible items must have the same payer as the negative credits being allocated.

Retum Premium Handling Schemes define the rules for credit allocation. Each scheme has a context that corresponds to a billing instruction type. The Default Retum Premium Plan has two handling schemes:

Cancellation, which defines rules for Cancellation billing instructions only Other, which defines rules for all other billing instruction types

Every return premium plan must have an "Other" context, which serves as the catch-all context. It must be the last context in the ordered list of contexts

For more information about return premium plans, refer to the BillingCenter Application Guide.

slides.title: Return premium handling schemes
slides.originalNotes:
Return premium handling schemes
BillingCenter processes policy credits on a charge-by-charge basis. For each negative charge, it looks for a match between the billing instruction type and the return premium handling scheme context. BillingCenter picks the first scheme that matches the current context and uses it for allocating the policy credits. So only one premium handling scheme is used for each negative charge.

The slide shows the list of allowable values for each field of a return premium handling scheme. The Excess Treatment field offers only one choice, Unapplied. However, a configuration developer can implement other treatments for excess policy credit, such as placing excess credits in suspense for later allocation or disbursing the credits.

slides.title: Credit allocation methods (2 of 2)
slides.originalNotes:
Credit allocation methods (2 of 2)
On the day the policy was issued, the premium was reduced by $600. For a policy change, the default allocation method is Proportional. BillingCenter allocates the credit proportionally over the eligible invoice items.

The Proportional allocation method can be affected by the placement dates of the unpaid invoice items and the credit items that are allocated. A credit item can be allocated to pay an invoice item only when the item’s placement date is the same or later than the credit item’s placement date. See the BillingCenter Application Gude for details.

For cancellation charges, the default allocation method is Last to First. BillingCenter states with the eligible item having the latest placement date, fully allocating the credit to each item.

There is a third credit allocation method, First to Last, which is seldom used.

slides.title: Cancellation
slides.originalNotes:
Setting the context
Marcus is interested to know how BillingCenter handles policy cancellations. Zhang explains that BillingCenter never directly cancels a policy. Instead, it informs the PAS that a policy is past due. The PAS decides to cancel the policy and determines the final amount that must be billed. It sends this information to BillingCenter. BillingCenter compares this amount with the amount of money received. It can then bill for the final amount or send a refund (disbursement).

slides.title: Policy cancellation overview (1 of 2)
slides.originalNotes:
Policy cancellation overview (I of 2)
A policy cancellation is a transaction that ends a policy before its expiration date. Cancellations can be initiated either by the policyholder or the insurer. Cancellations initiated by the insurer usually take longer to complete, as there are typically regulations mandating that the insurer inform the policyholder of the intent to cancel a certain amount of time before the policy can be canceled.

Cancellations typically include negative charges. The negative charges are credits for coverage that will not be provided because the policy is ending early. Cancellations can also have positive charges, such as a charge for a processing fee or a charge to remove discounts that the policy no longer qualifies for as a result of the cancellation. Generally, any positive charges are smaller than the negative charges, and the sum of allcharges on a cancellation is typically negative.

slides.title: Policy cancellation overview (1 of 2)
slides.originalNotes:
Policy cancellation overview (I of 2)
Cancellation processing invoices slicing cancellation charges into invoice items and assigning the items to planned invoices. Then the invoice items from negative charges are allocated to pay for existing unpaid positive invoice items. This process is called policy credit allocation. BillingCenter collapses all planned invoices into a single invoice. However, before collapsing the invoices, BillingCenter takes snapshots of the invoice items on the policy period's planned invoices. Subsequently, if the canceled policy is reinstated, BillingCenter can use the snapshots to restore the planned invoices to a state that is as close as possible to their original state.

Cancellation processing (after snapshots taken)
In the diagram, there are four invoices: a billed invoice and three planned invoices. Each invoice has a positive invoice item (represented as green rectangles). BillingCenter makes snapshots of the existing invoice items before it slices the cancellationcharge.

The next step in cancellation processing is to slice the cancellation charges into invoice items and place the invoice items on invoices based on the invoice item placement dates. The example assumes a cancellation billing instruction with a negative charge, which is sliced into three invoice items (represented as red rectangles) and placed on the planned invoices.
Step 2 shows policy credits being allocated from the negative invoice items to pay for any unsettled invoice items. The negative invoice items (represented as red rectangles) are allocated to pay for the unsettled invoice items. The credits are applied "last to first"- The invoice items that have been paid through credit allocation are represented as white rectangles with green outlines. The credits paid in full for the positive invoice item on the April 15 invoice- The credits also partially paid for the positive invoice item on March 15. The invoice item on February 15, which is the earliest planned invoice, remains unpaid.
The final step is to collapse all future invoices onto a single planned invoice- The invoice items for the planned invoices are moved onto the earliest planned invoice- This step ensures that the outstanding balance for a canceled policy (if there is one) is billed on a single invoice.

If the account uses policy- level billing, the earliest planned invoice will typically be the last invoice for the canceled policy- All other planned invoices will have no invoice items on them, and BillingCenter will delete those invoices- If the account uses account-level billing, the earliest planned invoice will typically be the last invoice to contain invoice items for the canceled policy- However, there may still be additional planned invoices to bill for other policies.

slides.title: Policy reinstatement overview
slides.originalNotes:
Policy reinstatement overview
By default, when processing a policy cancellation, BillingCenter takes snapshots of the invoice items on a policy period’s planned invoices before collapsing them into a single invoice. Ifthe policy is later reinstated, BillingCenter attempts to use these snapshots to restore the planned invoices to a state that is as close to their original state as possible.

A reinstatement typically has one or more charges. Most of the charges exist to reinstate the billing requirements for the portion of the policy that was canceled. There may also be a reinstatement fee charge.

When a given reinstatement charge can be matched to one or more invoice item snapshots, BillingCenter slices the charges so that they match, as closely as possible, the state of the invoices prior to cancellation.

If BillingCenter cannot find a cancellation snapshot for the policy to be reinstated, it usually slices the reinstatement charges according to payment plan settings. See the •Reinstatement“ topic in the BillingCenter Application Guide.

slides.title: A gap in coverage can occur
slides.originalNotes:
A gap in coverage can occur
Both reinstatements and cancellations have an effective date. The reinstatement effective date is the date that the policy becomes reinstated.

When a reinstatement effective date is the same as the effective date of the corresponding cancellation, there is no gap incoverage. Coverage is provided
as if the policy had never been canceled. In this case, the policy was restored as if it had never been canceled.

When a reinstatement effective date is later than the effective date of the corresponding cancellation, there is a gap in coverage. Any loss that occurs during this gap is not covered.

BillingCenter supports both reinstatements that have no gap in coverage and reinstatements that have a gap in coverage.

Note that some policy administration systems (including PolicyCenter) do not allow a reinstatement to have an effective date later than the corresponding cancellation. For these systems, if there is a gap in coverage, reinstating a policy must be implemented as a cancellation followed by a rewrite.

slides.title: Policy renewal overview
slides.originalNotes:
Policy renewal overview
A renewal is a policy transaction that creates a new policy period for an existing policy. Note that BillingCenter and PolicyCenter use the term "policy period" somewhat differently. In PolicyCenter, a policy period is one "version“ of a policy within the same policy term. In BillingCenter, a policy period roughly corresponds to a policy term because BillingCenter has no need to keep multiple versions of a policy.
BillingCenter has two types of billing instructions for renewals: renewal and new renewal. Renewal billing instructions are used when a policy is renewed and the billing for the previous policy term was executed by BillingCenter. New renewal billing instructions are used when a policy is renewed and the billing for the previous policy term was executed by a legacy billing system- In other words, new renewal billing instructions are for policies that are not new to the policy administration system but are new to BillingCenter.

BillingCenter processes a Renewal billing instruction using the usual payment plan and charge details and performs its normal charge invoicing process:
BillingCenter categorizes the renewal charges based on the charge’s charge pattern.
BillingCenter slices the charges into invoice items based on the policy's payment plan.
BillingCenter creates invoices and assigns the invoice items to the invoices based on the item event dates.

If you want to override how charge slicing is done for renewals, you can add an override to the payment plan for renewals. For example, you may want to implement continuous billing for renewals, avoiding a down payment and instead slicing Premium charges into a set of installments with no down payment.
BillingCenter supports renewal offer processing, where a policy is not bound until BillingCenter has received sufficient payment, without any configuration. See the BillingCenter Application Guide for more information.

slides.title: Policy rewrite overview
slides.originalNotes:
Policy rewrite overview
From a data perspective, rewrites are similar to renewals- They have a set of charges, a payment plan, and are optionally tied to one or more producers- A rewrite is associated with another policy period (the canceled policy period)- However, the rewrite has a new policy number unrelated to the one used by the previous policy period.

BillingCenter processes rewrites by executing the charge invoicing process in the same way that it processes newly issued policies:
1. BillingCenter categorizes the rewrite charges based on the charge’s charge pattern.
2. BillingCenter slices the charges into invoice items based on the policy's payment plan.
3. BillingCenter creates invoices and assigns the invoice items to the invoices based on the item event dates.

If you want to override how charge slicing is done for rewrites, you can add an override to the payment plan for rewrites. Here are some examples:

You may want to avoid a down payment for rewrites and instead slice Premium charges into a set of installments with no down payment
You may want to schedule one-time charges one way on newly issued policies and a different way on rewrites
